docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I am disheartened that the Senate proposal to redress insurance disparities between physical and mental ailments was dismissed in Congress (Week in Review, Dec. 30). I am employed by a company with very good health insurance. I am being treated for a mental illness that has plagued me for most of my life. I was 30 when I finally got help. What made the difference? Insurance. Prior attempts to get help failed because I did not have access to the medical care I needed.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Late in the discussion on parity for mental and physical health benefits (Week in Review, Dec. 30), we learn that the Domenici-Wellstone bill applies to all mental health conditions in the standard diagnostic manual ''with the exception of drug and alcohol addiction.'' Why leave out such a pervasive yet treatable disease? Only recently have patients seeking help for depressive neurosis, anxiety disorders and other painful conditions been taken seriously. Must addiction disease wait in line?
